author: Salman Khan
title: Boston Bruinsâ€™ Brandon Carlo Returns Post-Concussion, Adapts Gameplay to Safeguard Health
text:
Itchy Breasts: Unraveling Causes and Seeking Solutions
Boston Bruinsâ€™ Brandon Carlo Returns Post-Concussion, Adapts Gameplay to Safeguard Health
In a significant development for the Boston Bruins, defenseman Brandon Carlo is back on the ice, marking his return after a concussion he sustained on January 8, 2024. Notably, this isnâ€™t Carloâ€™s first brush with such a critical health concern â€“ an alarming factor that has necessitated a close examination of his condition and a cautious approach towards his return.
Brandon Carloâ€™s Concussion History
The issue of concussions has been a recurrent one in Carloâ€™s career, with the player having faced it multiple times. Never one to downplay the seriousness of the matter, Carlo has always been forthright about his condition. He has underscored the importance of not rushing back to the game, instead focusing on ensuring that he is in the right state of health before making a comeback.
Adapting to Reduce Risk
As a step towards safety, Carlo has adapted his playing style to limit high-impact hits. He remains conscious of the need to keep a check on any persisting symptoms, fully aware that his long-term brain health could be at stake. This is particularly relevant in light of the discussions around Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) â€“ a degenerative brain disease found in athletes with a history of repetitive brain trauma.
Bruinsâ€™ Lineup Boost
In addition to Carlo, the Bruins are seeing the return of Derek Forbort and Matt Poitras from their respective injuries. Additionally, goalie Linus Ullmark is back in action after a lower body injury that turned out to be less severe than initially believed. These returns mark a significant boost for the Bruins, strengthening their lineup and raising hopes for an improved performance.
Bruins Celebrate Centennial
Meanwhile, the Bruins have been celebrating their Centennial, paying tribute to teams from the late 1980s and early â€™90s. One of the highlights of the celebration has been the reminiscence of the end of a long playoff losing streak against the Montreal Canadiens in 1988. Former player Randy â€˜Stumpâ€™ Burridge fondly recalled the era and the enduring rivalry with the Canadiens, adding a touch of nostalgia to the teamâ€™s centenary celebrations.

title: ABI - ComisiÃ³n de Diputados aprueba crÃ©dito por $us 250 millones para sofocar incendios forestales
text: La Paz, 03 de octubre de 2024 (ABI). â€“ Por mayorÃ­a absoluta, la ComisiÃ³n de PlanificaciÃ³n de la CÃ¡mara de Diputados aprobÃ³ este jueves el crÃ©dito del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (BID) de $us 250 millones, para las tareas de sofocaciÃ³n de los incendios forestales que afectan al oriente de Bolivia. El presidente de la ComisiÃ³n de PlanificaciÃ³n, Omar Yujra, exhortÃ³ a sus colegas a ratificar la norma en la sesiÃ³n plenaria de la prÃ³xima semana, y hacer a un lado â€œelementos de corte polÃ­tico y demagÃ³gicosâ€. Este crÃ©dito de $us 250 millones fue canalizado por el BID, para ayudar a la emergencia por desastres naturales y salud pÃºblica. El organismo internacional aprobÃ³ el crÃ©dito en mayo y el Ejecutivo lo remitiÃ³ a la Asamblea Legislativa en septiembre. De acuerdo con el BID este prÃ©stamo contingente permitirÃ¡ ayudar a Bolivia a â€œconstruir mayor resiliencia financiera frente a inundaciones, sequÃ­as, incendios forestales y posibles brotes epidÃ©micos y pandÃ©micosâ€. El crÃ©dito se suma a otro por $us 75 millones, facilitado por el Banco de Desarrollo de AmÃ©rica Latina (CAF), para tambiÃ©n sofocar los incendios. Este segundo crÃ©dito es debatido en el pleno de la CÃ¡mara de Diputados, en virtud de un acuerdo multipartidario concretado por la presidenta en ejercicio VerÃ³nica Challco y que fue avalado por la mayorÃ­a de los legisladores en una resoluciÃ³n. author: VNExplorer
title: FMCG eye green shoots of growth in 2024
text:
The domestic FMCG market had reported a 9% year-on-year jump in September 2023 quarter sales and an 8.6% rise in volumes for the period. (Image/Reuters)
Fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) companies are counting on multiple factors for growth in the coming year. This includes commodity inflation, which is projected to keep product prices in check, the prospect of a favourable monsoon to boost rural growth, and the long-term trend of premiumisation, which is expected to keep urban growth going.
The year 2023 was marked by lower-than-expected festive demand, rainfall shortfall that limited rural growth, unseasonal showers that hampered the sale of beverages and ice-creams throughout the summer months, and inflationary pressures that kept rural customers mainly out of the market.
Saugata Gupta, MD & CEO, Marico, said: â€œWe expect the demand situation to improve by the next couple of quarters. Large players have increased their pace of innovation and premiumisation in urban areas. At the same time, players have focused on expanding rural distribution. Companies have also taken pricing action which should aid in good volume growth in the quarters ahead.â€
Also Read Import duty waiver for tur & urad extended till end of FY25
The domestic FMCG market had reported a 9% year-on-year jump in September 2023 quarter sales and an 8.6% rise in volumes for the period, market research agency NielsenIQ (NIQ) said in November, led by urban markets. Rural markets, despite showing indications of progress, still had a long way to go before fully recovering, according to the market research firm in its quarterly market analysis.
These signs of stress were apparent in kirana channel sales, which constitute 80% of an FMCG companyâ€™s business in India. Modern trade comprises 12-13% and e-commerce around 7-8% of sales for an FMCG company.
The festive season of October-November, an important period for consumer companies, was lack-lustre for kiranas as the offtake of products such as beauty, cosmetics, chocolate and confectionery was weak. This happened as consumers chose to cut back on expenditure in rural and semi-urban areas, officials at the All India Consumer Products Distributorsâ€™ Federation (AICPDF), an apex body of FMCG distributors, said.
A recent study by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) and the Boston Consulting Group said that while inflationary pressures and weather uncertainty had hurt rural consumption in 2023, an improvement in supply-side constraints and more people getting into the consumption basket could help reverse the trend in the future.
Also Read Year ahead: Oil markets may remain volatile in 2024 also
Companies have taken note of these changes saying that they are putting more feet on the ground to push their direct retail reach, especially in rural areas. At the same time, firms also saw the importance of revitalising general trade by pushing affordable packs, increasing innovation at the bottom-of-the-pyramid and reducing inventory pressure and clutter within stores.
â€œThough green shoots of recovery are visible, rural demand is still behind urban markets. There have been liquidity pressures in rural areas, which are reflected in poor offtakes during the festive season. However, we are hopeful of rural markets posting a strong recovery in the quarters ahead,â€ Mohit Malhotra, chief executive officer, Dabur India, said.
Prabha Narasimhan, MD & CEO of Colgate Palmolive India, says that companies need to focus on both urban and rural consumers to drive growth in the future.
â€œWe have become good at price-point packs with business being generated from them as they address consumers who have limited money. The other end of the spectrum are consumers who have money; I would urge companies to address those consumers and see if we are providing an adequate range of products,â€ Narasimhan said.
Asif Malbari, chief financial officer at Godrej Consumer Products, said he remained optimistic about growth in the coming year. â€œIn 2024, we expect an improved economic environment and lower volatility in commodity prices. We remain optimistic that our focus on market development will enable us to deliver market-beating volume growth,â€ Malbari said.
Also Read Cotton output may decline 8 per cent to 294.10 lakh bales this year: CAI
K Ramakrishnan, MD, South Asia, Kantar WorldPanel, said that growing categories had a strong rural and urban focus and that they were also active in terms of innovations at regular intervals.
â€œBrands in the growing categories are great responders to macro occurrences. They tailor-make perceptions around these trends,â€ Ramakrishnan said, citing the growth in hygiene and healthcare products during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Post-Covid, the â€œhygiene-awareâ€ and â€œsnacking intenseâ€ consumer had pushed up category contribution of segments such as noodles, biscuits and insecticides in overall volume change, Ramakrishnan said.
While packaged noodles had touched 78% in terms of contribution, biscuits and insecticides had touched 67% and 64% each in terms of contribution to volume change within FMCG, he said.

author: MUNDODEPORTIVO.COM
title: Goleada del Deportivo Fabril por 0-3 frente al Compostela
text:
El Deportivo Fabril redondeÃ³ una magnÃ­fica actuaciÃ³n ante al Compostela, al que goleÃ³ por 0-3 durante el encuentro celebrado en el Estadio Municipal Vero Boquete de San LÃ¡zaro este miÃ©rcoles. El Compostela afrontÃ³ el partido con la intenciÃ³n de remontar su puntuaciÃ³n en la clasificaciÃ³n tras perder el Ãºltimo partido frente al Coruxo por un marcador de 2-0. Por su parte, el Deportivo Fabril ganÃ³ fuera de casa 0-1 su Ãºltimo encuentro en la competiciÃ³n ante el Guijuelo. Gracias a este resultado, el conjunto coruÃ±Ã©s es quinto, mientras que el Compostela es decimoquinto al terminar el encuentro.
El encuentro comenzÃ³ de modo inmejorable para el conjunto coruÃ±Ã©s, que dio el silbatazo de salida en el Estadio Municipal Vero Boquete de San LÃ¡zaro gracias a un tanto de Guerrero a los 32 minutos. Tras esto, una nueva ocasiÃ³n permitiÃ³ incrementar el marcador del Deportivo Fabril, que aumentÃ³ el marcador con un gol de Ferreiro poco antes del final, concretamente en el 46, concluyendo la primera parte con el resultado de 0-2.
En el segundo periodo la suerte llegÃ³ para la escuadra visitante, que aumentÃ³ su cuenta goleadora con respecto a su rival con un tanto de Garrido a los 82 minutos, finalizando el enfrentamiento con un marcador final de 0-3.
Ambos entrenadores hicieron movimientos en los banquillos. El entrenador del Compostela dio entrada a Manu Barreiro, RodrÃ­guez, Selasi, Gil y Scorza por Hugo Matos, Markitos, Fausto, Fer Cano y Ãlvaro Casas, mientras que el Deportivo Fabril dio entrada a Carreira y DarÃ­o Germil por Mane y Kevin SÃ¡nchez.
En el partido el Ã¡rbitro amonestÃ³ con cuatro tarjetas amarillas solamente al equipo local. Concretamente, se mostrÃ³ tarjeta amarilla a Fausto, Rivas, De Prado y Carlos PÃ©rez.
Con esta buena exhibiciÃ³n el Deportivo Fabril asciende hasta los 43 puntos en la Segunda FederaciÃ³n y se queda en el quinto puesto de la clasificaciÃ³n. Por su parte, el Compostela se mantiene con 28 puntos, en posiciÃ³n de descenso a Tercera DivisiÃ³n, con los que llegaba a la vigÃ©sima jornada.
En la prÃ³xima cita del calendario, ambos equipos jugarÃ¡n en su feudo. El Compostela se enfrentarÃ¡ al BergantiÃ±os mientras que el Deportivo Fabril lo harÃ¡ contra el Real AvilÃ©s.

author: Katie Bowlby
title: HGTV Fans Praise Erin Napier for Sharing "Disorganized" Photos of Her Home
text: We're officially in the New Year, but we have to admit that mentally we're not ready for the cozy holiday season to end. That magical, restful time between December 25 and January 1 passes too quickly. Luckily, HGTV star [Erin Napier](https://www.countryliving.com/life/a45576520/home-town-star-erin-napier-best-seller/) took a moment to chronicle some special moments from her family's holiday, so we can reflect back on that cozy time. It is undoubtedly a busy time for Erin and [Ben Napier](https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a45735348/hgtv-ben-napier-home-town-season-8-new-character/), as their popular [Home Town show](https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a46054695/ben-erin-napier-home-town-season-7-interview/) returns to HGTV for its [seventh season](https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a45850766/ben-erin-napiers-home-town-hgtv-return/) on January 7. But, judging by the photos Erin [shared on Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/p/C1abnIcpI0V), the parents of two young girls know how to embrace their downtime as a family. Erin's post included photos of her Christmas decorations, kids' toys on the kitchen counter, a handmade gingerbread house, and daughters Helen (who just turned 6!) and Mae (2) playing by the tree. Fans were quick to praise her for keeping it real on social media, as usual. They left comments like, "I love to see a home thatâ€™s LIVED IN. â¤ï¸ Thank you for sharing these shots," "Absolutely my favorite time of the holidays!!! Itâ€™s peaceful and messy and perfect," and "Itâ€™s all about the perfectly imperfect gingerbread house under the dome for me.â¤ï¸" Of course, this is the spirit of Erin's best-selling book, [Heirloom Rooms](https://www.amazon.com/Heirloom-Rooms-Soulful-Stories-Home/dp/1982190434/ref=sr_1_1), which showcases the "beautifully imperfect, lived-in spaces" of Erin and her loved ones. To see more of Erin's style, tune in to Home Town on Sunday at 8 p.m. EST/7 p.m. CST on HGTV or stream episodes on [Max](https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=74968X1525072&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.max.com%2F). Katie Bowlby is Digital Director at Country Living, where she covers gift guides, product reviews, crafts, and TV shows like Yellowstone. Sheâ€™s currently stitching up a cross-stitch pattern for the magazineâ€™s next issue

author: Beth Newhart
title: Farmers sound the alarm as concerning conditions point to future crisis: 'Their math does not add up'
text:
Extreme drought conditions in Argentina are affecting the harvest season and leading farmers to rethink what they can expect in the future.
What's happening? Significantly dry weather in the country since the beginning of the year is producing smaller and fewer overall crops than usual, according to a report in Reuters .
Dario Sabini, a farmer from Argentina, said that even though official estimates have already lowered the harvest forecast in response to the drought, it will likely turn out to be even worse.
"Their math does not add up," he said.
"It has to rain. Hopefully it will rain soon and we can improve [yields]," said Juan Gardey, a soybean farmer. "It's very complicated."
Why is it important? Argentina produces and exports a huge amount of grains every year. With fewer viable crops, not only will the farmers directly lose income, but the economy of the country will suffer, and there will be less food to go around.
Watch now: Giant snails invading New York City? It's estimated that every week without rain during this harvest season could result in a loss of 5 million tons of each crop. Soy and corn are likely to end up with about 40 million tons each, a steep drop from last year's output of about 50 million each.
With the changing climate causing extreme weather such as drought and floods, this could be an early glimpse at troubling future harvest seasons. Scientists have recently warned that prolonged "megadroughts" are increasing worldwide.
What's being done about it? The Argentinian government cut taxes on agricultural exports until summer to generate quicker sales and income for the country.

Unfortunately, farmers said the problem can't be solved that easily. The price changes are small, and the farmers are still low on stock and can't meet demand.
Conserving and recycling water is important for areas experiencing drought , but that's not always possible for farmers. Turning to renewable energy sources, cutting pollution, and other sustainable choices need to be implemented at a large scale to combat the effects of the warming climate and avoid dangerous weather.
